 People seem to have a difficult time understanding her condition. She is not in a coma, she is not unconscious, she is not hadicapped, she is not simply unable to feed herself. She is profoundly brain damaged. This is what occurs when you suffer a cardiac arrest with a down time greater than a few minutes. Brain cells die due to a lack of or depleated supply of oxygen. Like cardiac cells, once brain cells are dead, they DO NOT regenerate  themselves. There is no technology capable of making these cells come back to life. In fact, the research aimed at making that technology possible in the future (stem cell research) is strongly opposed by the republicans. Sounds like pandering for the congressional vote to me. Terri is not brain dead, as her "brain stem" (the part responsible for regulation of cardiac and respiratory cycles) is still functioning. The rest of her brain is dead. And the rest of the brain, is what makes us sentient human beings. With the type of damage that has occured to Terri's brain, she does not even know that she is alive, it is a physical impossibility.

 Terri was evaluated by Dr. Ron Cranford, a neurologist at The University of Minnesota in 2001. This was a court ordered evaluation. These evaluations involved both an EEG and a CT scan of the brain. They revealed no electrical activity (detectable any time neurotransmitters are released into the synapse) in the cerebral cortex, and massive atrophy (wasting of tissue) of the cerebral cortex. The cerebral cortex is the area of the brain responsible for memory, thinking, awareness, language, and consciousness. In other words, the part of Terri that once made her human and conscious of her environment are dead. How can this be disputed? If the EEG shows a flat line, the part of the brain being examined is dead. Unfortunately for Terri, brain tissue cannot regenrate...so once it is dead, it is dead. There is no chance of recovery for Terri. That is a medical and scientific certainty.

 I was willing to give him the benefit of the doubt...at first. But, then there were too many actions on his part that led me to assume more nefarious reasons. Here's a partial timeline of events:
 
1992
 Aug - Terri awarded $250,000 in malpractice settlement.
 Nov - Terri awarded $1.4 million in malpractice trial.
 Nov - Michael Schiavo awarded $600,000 in malpractice trial.
 1993
 Feb - Michael Schiavo denies recommended rehabilitation treatment.
 Feb - Schiavo and Terri's parents have falling out regarding lack of therapy for Terri.
 Feb - Schiavo withholds medical information from Terri's parents.
 Feb - Schiavo posts Do not Resuscitate order in Terri's medical chart.
 Jun - Schiavo threatens Schindler family with lawsuit.
 Aug - Schiavo orders medical staff not to treat Terri for potentially fatal infection.
 Sep - Bob and Mary Schindler petition courts to remove Schiavo as Terri's guardian.
 Nov - Schiavo admits in deposition that he knew withholding treatment of infection could result in Terri's death.
 
 and later in 2000
 2000
 Jan - Judge Greer Conducts Terri's Feeding Tube Removal Trial.
 Feb - Greer Rules to Remove Nutrition Feeding Tube.
 Feb - Affidavits filed by 3 doctors state Terri can swallow and is not PVS.
 Feb - Greer denies petition to allow Terri swallowing tests.
 Apr - Terri Moved from Palm Gardens Nursing Home to Hospice Facility.
 Apr - Greer denies motion to return Terri to Palm Garden Nursing home.
 Apr - Greer imposes restricted visitor list for Terri.
 Jul - Appeal filed with Appellate Court to overturn Greer's verdict.
 Nov - Appellate Court Conducts Oral Arguments.
 http://www.terrisfight.net/

 The problem is that, contrary to what ABC News told those polled, Terri Schiavo is not on "life support" and has never been on "life support." The loaded phrase evokes images of a comatose patient being artificially sustained by myriad machines and pumps and wires. Terri was on a feeding tube. A feeding tube is not a ventilator. Terri can breathe just fine on her own.
 
 And as many of her medical caretakers and parents have argued, if given proper rehabilitation, Terri could learn to chew and swallow on her own as well. She is disabled, not dead.
 
 But ABC News did not see fit to inform either the poll takers or its viewers of the truth. Instead, it misled them -- and the result was a poll response that produced -- voila! -- "broad public disapproval" for any government intervention to spare Terri from slowly starving to death. Blogger Ed Morrissey of Captain's Quarters (captainsquartersblog.com) noted: "Either ABC is completely incompetent in conducting research, or they have attempted to fool their viewers and readership with false polling that essentially lies about the case in question. Since when does ABC conduct push polling for euthanasia?"

 She is not "totally" brain dead. If she were, she would already be dead. Her "lower brain", which contains the cardio-respiratory center is still functioning, although damaged by the hypoxia as well. Her cerebral cortex "upper brain", the part responsible for consciousness and such has actually died, been broken down, and replaced by cerebrospinal fluid (fluid found in the brain and spinal column). It is estimated that only 5-10% of the "upper brain" remains in Terri, and this has been shown by EEG (an electrical measurement of brain activity) to be non-functional. Brain cells do not regenerate meaning there is no chance of improvement. While technically, Terri's body may be capable of sending a chemical pain impulse from a part of her body, to the reflex center in the spine / lower brain, she does not have the upper brain to actually perceive the pain. 
 
 This is unlike a person in a coma, who's brain is "stunned" and not truely damaged. A coma is typically the result of a traumatic brain injury which can cause swelling, and damage to the neural pathways which carry the electrical transmissions in the brain. More often than not, these types of injuries cause little to no hypoxia in the brain, therefore far less brain tissue actually dies. People in a coma typically do not have extensive brain damage, and often regain consciousness. Many (certainly not all) recall sensations, pain, even conversations that were held around them while they were in the coma. Terri is not in a coma. There is a huge difference, and I think that perhaps many people are not able to make this distinction. I am willing to bet that many of Terri's "supporters" think that it is possible for Terri to wake up like a coma victim might. This is just not the case.

 2.) Terri's condition is a persistent vegatative state. She stopped breathing for whatever reason. Don't believe everything you read in the paper. Her state has deteriorated to the point of complete pvs. The brainscan shows her cerebral cortex. A deteriorating membrane on top of which rests cerebral-spinal fluid.
 
 3.) Most likely, no one will ever know why this happened to Terri; a relatively healthy 25 year old woman. The interesting part about this is that original prognosis included possibilities of suffocation and asphixiation. Broken bones and bruises from her legs to her neck indicated possible physical attack and were later dismissed as 'unfounded' in a court of law. They were pawned off as damages from seizure during her 'heart attack'. Later, the prognosis became that she suffered from a lack of 'potassium', an element that helps fire brain neurons and carry oxygen throughout the body. Lack of potassium in most patients causes the development of arthritis, body pains, and numbness as precursors of a serious condition. Potassium, like flouride, is found in most drinking water.
 
 I got around to thinking about this. Potassium can be blocked or removed by certain chemicals and poisons. Scorpions, snakes, and even more commonly, household pesticides, can completely alter potassium levels and cause neurons to misfire or stop firing. Pesticides are not commonly tested in blood tests. Just an interesting tidbit.

Sarah Scantlin and Terry Wallis are two people who, within the last 2 years, have both awakened from 20 year comas. Their stories are legendary and unheard of in science and raises new suspicions by scientists that the brain is, infact, capable of regeneration.  The difference is that someone that's in a coma ONLY has a chance of coming out of it. The recently completed autopsy showed that Terri's brain had decomposed in many areas (for a lack of better words). There was no hope of her ever regaining normal brain functions.

The question is simply this: What does Terry Schiavo want? The question is not "what would I want If I were in this state?". Terry Schiavo's rights in this regard are being ignored. We speak of Terry's right to be allowed to die but if she does not wish to die then we would be violating her right to decide to live. As long as we do not know HER wishes, we should not remove the feeding tube. Terry's life does not belong to anyone else, not the husband, not the parents, not the state or the taxpayers or the lawyers or the judge. It belongs to her and it is our government's role to uphold HER right to decide to die or live whatever her decision is.

I see three major problems with Terri's case:
 
 1) Michael Schiavo should not have been the guardian. Having the spouse as guardian is a reasonable default, but it should be open to challenge. Certainly it would be unreasonable to appoint the spouse as guardian after a couple had filed for divorce, and once Michael moved on with his life - moved in with his girlfriend and started a family with her - there is not a court in the country that would have denied Terri a divorce. But Judge George Greer made certain that Terri had no one to speak for her.
 
 2) Terri's wishes: Several years after the original incident (and after the malpractice suit money came in), Michael and a couple of his relatives submitted affadavits that Terri would not have wanted to live in that condition. Several of Terri's friends submitted affadavits that, for the first few years, they had heard Michael tell people that he had no idea what Terri would have wanted. In a classic case of he said / she said, based on hearsay evidence that would not support a $10 fine for jaywalking, Judge George Greer sentenced Terri to death. 
 
 The appellate courts looked only for dotted i's and crossed t's, but none of them ever reviewed the facts of the case. I can guarantee that if Terri had been sentenced on the basis of an alleged crime, the appellate courts would have fallen all over themselves to send the case back for retrial. But there was no crime.
 
 3) The method of execution was slow and barbaric, far beyond "cruel and unusual." Terri's mother was denied the opportunity to offer any comfort to her dying daughter - water for her parched lips, or a sliver of ice for her swollen tongue. What was Judge George Greer afraid of? Was he afraid she would choke to death and end her suffering too early? Or was he afraid that she wouldn't choke to death?
 
 -----------
 
 Terri was executed. A feeding tube is not life support. It is perhaps more complex than a prosthetic limb or false teeth, but less complex than a pacemaker. Terri was not terminal; she was an extreme case of severely disabled - and this case is a horrible precedent for our society.

 Actually, a feeding tube is not nearly as complex as a prosthetic limb. It is simply a rubber or plastic tube put in into either the stomach or small intestine which provides liquid nutrients (basically a nutritional shake) to the Pt. Why is it not life support? A life support implement only does what the Pt. is incapable of doing for themselves.  Life support, in the medical field, refers to a set of therapies for preserving a patient's life when essential body systems are not functioning sufficiently to sustain life unaided. Life support therapies utilize some combination of several techniques: emoticon_ic feeding tubes emoticon_ic , intravenous drips, total parenteral nutrition, mechanical respiration, heart/lung bypass, defibrillation, urinary catheterization and dialysis. The court used only hearsay evidence (the only kind available) which would not be adequate to sustain a $10 fine for jaywalking.
 
 
In Florida, if you are incapacitated, your spouse is your guardian. There is no way around this, unles you petition the court to assign another guardian.
And the judge made sure that no one else would be allowed to speak for her.
 
 The case was a tragic miscarriage of justice and set a disgraceful standard for treatment of the severely disabled.

Yes he did. He could have petitioned the court to be removed from guardianship, and/or he could have requested a divorce.

 
 No, he counldn't. What aprt of "HE DID NOT MAKE THE DECISION" do you not understand? If he had divorced her or petitioned the court to remove the guardianship, it would have changed NOTHING. THE COURT made the decision to allow her to die. Even if his parents had been handed guardianship, she STILL would have died, because the court had already ordered it. The original court, acting as her guardian in the matter, determined that this is what she would want, and it was upheld under multiple appeals. People seem to have this misconception that this was a battle between her husbands and her parents. That is simply incorrect, though it does immediatly show that the person in quesiton lacks even a basic grasp of the facts of the case. 
 
 I personally don't understand how so many morally rightous folks out there can claim that THEY know more about the case, and what Terri would have wanted, than the court, who literally took hundreds of hours of testimony, statements from independant doctors appointed, and paid for, BY THE COURT (despite the rediculous claims that only the doctors hired by him found that she was in a PVS).
 
 
The court used only hearsay evidence (the only kind available) which would not be adequate to sustain a $10 fine for jaywalking.

 
 Do you even understand the concept of hearsay evidence? If I am on the witness stand, and I say "My neiborgh bob told me he killed his wife", that is not hearsay evidecne, that is eye witness testimony, which is one of the strongest types of evidence you can present in court (unless the witness is discredited, as her parents were). If I get up ont he stand and say "fred down the street told me that bob told him that he killed his wife", that is hearsay evidence and is inadmissable in most cases (exceptions may be made if bob killed fred as well). NO hearsay evidence was admitted in ANY of the hearings. ONE witness presented hearsay on the stand and their testimony was thrown out. 
 
 
And the judge made sure that no one else would be allowed to speak for her.

 
 Except, of course, for the 38 witnesses and 9 different doctors. The only witensses who testified that they had heard her calim that she would not want to die in such a circumstance were her parents, and their testimony was so badly discredited that if the circumstances of the case had been different (not so emotionally charged), they would probably have been charged with perjury, and rightly so.
 
 
The case was a tragic miscarriage of justice and set a disgraceful standard for treatment of the severely disabled.

 
 I am interested to hear how you drew your conclusions in this case. No disrespoect intended, I am just interested in your thought processes here. When I first heard fo the whole mess, I researched the case. I read the court findings, some fo the witness testimony, took a look ath the statements provided by the court appointed doctors, and formed an opinion. You do not seem to be in posession of ANY facts whatsoever, to the point of being clueless as to who actually made the decision, what kind of testimony and evidence was offered, or even who the major players really were as far as who was on the different sides fo the dispute. 
 
 How did you form an opinion on this? You certainly seem to have not just an opinion, but an exceptionally strong opinion, yet you have clearly demonstrated that it is in no way based on the facts fo the case. Is it purely an emotional response?
 
 Again, no offense intended, just wondering.
See post #194, which rebuts your arguments.

See post #194, which rebuts your arguments.

 
 Post 194 does not even adress my arguments, because, once again, it shows a complete ignorance of the facts in the case.
 
 Here is post 194 and my comments:
 
 
I see three major problems with Terri's case:

 
 That is becuase you are completely ignorant of the facts surrounding it.
 
 
1) Michael Schiavo should not have been the guardian. Having the spouse as guardian is a reasonable default, but it should be open to challenge. Certainly it would be unreasonable to appoint the spouse as guardian after a couple had filed for divorce, and once Michael moved on with his life - moved in with his girlfriend and started a family with her - there is not a court in the country that would have denied Terri a divorce. But Judge George Greer made certain that Terri had no one to speak for her.

 
 And it is opne to challenge. If there is any evidence at all that the person in quesiton is beign abused, or that they are not acting in the best intersts of their ward, the court will pull the plug. Even her parents did not argue that abuse was occuring, and the courts had already ruled that the course he was taking was what she would have wanted....they ruled that there was clear and compelling evidence for this. 
 
 You seem to be arguing two opposite sides at the same time. On the one hand, you seem to be sayiung that he should have spent his life pining away for his already deaad wife. On the other you seem to be arguing that he should have essentially disowned her. You can't have it both ways. If I was ever in a similar situation, I would hope that my wife would move on with her life and be happy. At the same time, though, I would hope that she would not just disavow me.
 
 
2) Terri's wishes: Several years after the original incident (and after the malpractice suit money came in), Michael and a couple of his relatives submitted affadavits that Terri would not have wanted to live in that condition. Several of Terri's friends submitted affadavits that, for the first few years, they had heard Michael tell people that he had no idea what Terri would have wanted. In a classic case of he said / she said, based on hearsay evidence that would not support a $10 fine for jaywalking, Judge George Greer sentenced Terri to death.

 
 You have not established any hearsay evidence. We already covered what constitutes hearsay. 
 
 What you are missing here is the fact (yes, I know, andother pesky fact) that her prognosis changed. Up to that point, there was actually some very small hope for recovery. At that point (about 3-4 years intot he ordeal), it became apparent that her brain was actually disappearing. It was being replaced with cerebral fluid. At that point, there was ABSOLUTELY NO HOPE FOR RECOVERY. Her brain was simply diapearing. Everything that made Terri Terri was dead, and was beign absorbed by the body as dead tissue generaly is.
 
 Even if this had not changed, it makes no difference. Michaels testimony was not even pivitol to the case. It is interesting that you bring upo her friends who submitted the affidavids, since all of them but one retracted their statements before the actual trial, and the one who did not was the ONLY witness whose testimony was ruled to be hearsay and was thrown out. Apparently in her affidavid and testimony she claimed that she had heard Michael make the statement that he had no idea what terri would want. She claimed she was at a social event. Later it was shown that Micahel was not even at the event in question, and that the conversation in question never took place. She then changed her story and claimed that somebody else there had related the conversation to her. That was the only hearsay presented int he entire case.
 
 
The appellate courts looked only for dotted i's and crossed t's, but none of them ever reviewed the facts of the case. I can guarantee that if Terri had been sentenced on the basis of an alleged crime, the appellate courts would have fallen all over themselves to send the case back for retrial. But there was no crime.

 
 Wrong again. The primary purpose of appeal was the question of whether the "clear and convincing" burden of evidence had been obtained. Not only did they review every shred of evidence int he case, including the hudreds of hours of witness testimony, they also listened to a whole slew of witnesses present first hand testimony. This took place twice on appeal, so the entire body of evidence was weighed by 3 different courts, and a whole truckload of judges. any one fo those courts could have found differently. No judge that ever weighed the evidence saw fit to do so.
 
 
3) The method of execution was slow and barbaric, far beyond "cruel and unusual." Terri's mother was denied the opportunity to offer any comfort to her dying daughter - water for her parched lips, or a sliver of ice for her swollen tongue. What was Judge George Greer afraid of? Was he afraid she would choke to death and end her suffering too early? Or was he afraid that she wouldn't choke to death?

 
 Thisis just stupid. She was not executed. She was allowed to die. More to the point, since her brain was already dead, her body was allowed to catch up. If you feed her or give her water, it would have just drawn it out, making the death even longer.
 
 Her mother was not allowed to be there because frankly her family behaved like a bunch of jackasses. 
 
 End her suffering too early? She was not suffering. Her brain was gone. The lights were on, but there was nobody home. There was no suffering. I would have thought the results of the autopsey would have shut the crowd that was constatnly railing about the inhumanity of her death up. She was no longer a sentient being. She was a breathing corpse.

Still too sketchy for me to decide one way of the other. For example, in 1993, Michael Schiavo was awarded $1Million because doctors failed to diagnose Terri's bulimia. That rings all sorts of bells with me because I've been down that road personally and wonder how much Michael was aware of Terri's eating disorder. If he knew her THAT well, you'd have thought that he would have pressed for treatment for his wife before her cardiacv arrest. If he didn't know, then why on earth would anyone make the leap of faith to assume that he knew her wishes about dying?
 Nah, every time I dig into this, I keep getting more shovelfuls of horse manure. emoticon_confused 
 
 The only thing that I'm sure of is that Terri had little brain function when she died.

 
 So what you are saying here, is that if he did not know about her bulemia, he could not have known about her wishes if she was incapacitated? That is rediculous. Discussing end of life issues with your spouse, and discussing your self inflicted illness with your spouse are 2 different things. People hide things like bulemia, drug addictions, gambling problems, and extramarital affairs from their spouse all the time. I see no correlation between him knowing her end of life wishes and him knowing or not knowing about her bulemia.

 Yes, I did know a bulemic. I spent my 3rd and 4th years at college on a medical campus at a regional trauma center. There were about 50 of us there, so we got to know each other quite well. What we did not know, or even suspect, was that one of the girls who was there with us was bulemic. We did not find out until she was taken to the ER one night with an irregular heart beat. Apparently, she had been bulemic for at least 3 years prior to this night, and nobody had ever put 2 and 2 together. I'm not saying that we slept in her room with her every night, but living on one floor in a dormatory with 50 people for 10 months a year, you tend to get to know people. And when the other 40+ of us who are either trained to some level or in training in the medical field miss it, yes, I would say that there is the possibility that people can conceal their illness.
